tn.text: This is the next part of the story. It is the Sabbath and Jesus is at Pharisee's house. Verse 1 gives background information about the setting of the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
This indicates a new event. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])
"to eat" or "for a meal." Bread was an important part of a meal and is used in this sentence to refer to a meal. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
They wanted to see if they could accuse him of doing anything wrong.

tn.ref: Behold, there in front of him was a man
tn.text: The word "behold" alerts us to a new person in the story. Your language may have a way of doing this. English uses "There in front of him was a man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
Edema is swelling caused by water building up in parts of the body. Some languages may have a name for this condition. AT: "was suffering because parts of his body were swollen with water"

tn.ref: Is it lawful to heal on the Sabbath, or not?
tn.text: "Does the law permit us to heal on the Sabbath, or does it forbid it?"
The religious leaders refused to answer Jesus' question.

tn.ref: So Jesus took hold of him
tn.text: "So Jesus took hold of the man who suffered from edema"

tn.ref: Which of you who has a son or an ox ... will not immediately pull him out?
tn.text: Jesus uses a question because he wanted them to admit that they would help their son or ox, even on the Sabbath. Therefore, it was right for him to heal people even on the Sabbath. AT: "If one of you has a son or an ox ... you would surely pull him out immediately" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: They were not able to give an answer
tn.text: They knew the answer and that Jesus was right, but they did not want to admit that he was correct. AT: "They had nothing to say"
Jesus continues to speak to the guests at the house of the Pharisee who had invited him to a meal.
It may be helpful to identify these people, and to state this in active form. AT: "those whom the leader of the Pharisees had invited to the meal" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"the seats for honored people" or "the seats for important people"

tn.ref: When you are invited by someone
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "When someone invites you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: When you ... than you ... say to you ... you will proceed
tn.text: These occurrences of "you" are singular. Jesus is speaking to the group as if to each individual person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: because someone may have been invited who is more honored than you
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "because the host may have invited a person who is more important than you are" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This occurrence of "you" refers to the two people who want the same seat of honor. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
"and then you will feel ashamed and"
"the least important place" or "the place for the least important person"
Jesus continues speaking to the people at the Pharisee's house.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "when someone invites you to a meal" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"the seat meant for the least important person"
"move to a seat for a more important person"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "Then the one who invited you will honor you" or "Then those who sit at the table will honor you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"who tries to look important" or "who takes an important position"
"will be shown to be unimportant" or "will be given an unimportant position." This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will humble" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"who chooses to look unimportant" or "who takes an unimportant position"
"will be shown to be important" or "will be given an important position." This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will exalt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Jesus continues speaking at the Pharisee's house, but addresses his host directly.

tn.ref: the man who had invited him
tn.text: "the Pharisee who had invited him to his house for a meal"
"you" is singular because Jesus is speaking directly to the Pharisee that invited him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
This probably does not mean they can never invite these people. More likely it means they should invite others as well. AT: "do not only invite" or "do not always invite"
"because they might"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "in this way they will repay you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Jesus continues speaking to the Pharisee who had invited him to his home.
It may be helpful to add "also" since this statement is probably not exclusive. AT: "also invite the poor"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will bless you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"they cannot invite you to a banquet in return"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will repay you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This refers to the final judgment. AT: "when God brings the righteous people back to life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
One of the men at the table speaks to Jesus and Jesus responds to him by telling a parable. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])

tn.ref: one of them who sat at the table
tn.text: This introduces a new person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
The man was not talking about a specific person. AT: "Blessed is anyone who" or "How good it is for everyone"
The word "bread" is used to refer to the whole meal. AT: "he who will eat at the meal" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Jesus begins telling a parable. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])
This phrase is a way of referring to the man without giving any specific information about his identity.
"invited many people" or "invited many guests"
"At the time for the dinner" or "When the dinner was about to begin"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "those he had invited" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Jesus continues telling his parable.
All of the people who were invited gave the servant excuses about why they could not come to the banquet.
"to say why they could not come to the dinner"
"Please forgive me" or "Please accept my apology"
Oxen were used in pairs to pull farming tools. AT: "10 oxen to work in my fields" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Use an expression that is natural in your language. Some languages may say "gotten married" or "taken a wife."
"became angry with the people he had invited"
"invite in here to eat the dinner"

It may be necessary to state clearly the implied information that the servant did what the master commanded him. AT: "After the servant went out and did that, he came back and said" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: what you commanded has been done
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "I have done what you commanded" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Jesus finishes his parable.
This refers to roads and paths outside of the city. AT: "the main roads and paths outside of the city"
"demand that they come in"

tn.ref: that my house may be filled
tn.text: "so that people may fill my house"
The word "you" is plural, so it is unclear to whom it is addressed. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
The word here for "men" means "male adults" and not just people in general.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "whom I invited" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"will enjoy the dinner I have prepared"
Jesus begins to teach the crowd that was traveling with him.

tn.ref: If anyone comes to me and does not hate his own father ... he cannot be my disciple
tn.text: Here, "hate" is an exaggeration to show how important it is to love Jesus much more than anyone else. AT: "If anyone comes to me and does not love me more than he loves his father ... he cannot be my disciple" or "Only if a person loves me more than he loves his own father ... can he be my disciple" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])

tn.ref: Whoever does not carry his own cross and come after me cannot be my disciple
tn.text: This could be stated with positive verbs. AT: "If anyone wants to be my disciple, he must carry his own cross and follow me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])

Jesus does not mean every Christian must be crucified. The Romans often made people carry their own crosses before they crucified them as a sign of their submission to Rome. This metaphor means they must submit to God and be willing to suffer in any way to be Jesus' disciples. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Jesus continues to explain to the crowd that it is important to count the cost of being a disciple.

tn.ref: For which of you, who desires to build a tower, does not first sit down and count the cost to calculate if he has what he needs to complete it?
tn.text: Jesus uses this question to prove that people count the cost of a project before they begin it. AT: "If a person wanted to build a tower, he would certainly first sit down and determine if he had enough money to complete it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This may have been a watchtower. AT: "a tall building" or "a high lookout platform."
It may be helpful to give more information. AT: "If he does not first count the cost" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: when he has laid a foundation
tn.text: "when he has built a base" or "when he has completed the first part of the building"

It is understood that he was not able to finish because he did not have enough money. This could be stated. AT: "does not have enough money to be able to finish" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Jesus continues to explain to the crowd that it is important to count the cost of being a disciple.
Jesus used this word to introduce another situation where people count the cost before making a decision.

tn.ref: what king ... will not sit down first and take advice ... men?
tn.text: Jesus uses another question to teach the crowd about counting the cost. AT: "you know that a king ... would sit down first and take counsel ... men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Possible meanings are 1) "think carefully about" or 2) "listen to his advisors."
"10,000 ... 20,000" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
It may be helpful to state more information. AT: "And if he realizes that he will not be able to defeat the other king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
"terms to end the war" or "what the other king wants him to do in order to end the war"

tn.ref: any one of you who does not give up all that he has cannot be my disciple
tn.text: This can be stated with positive verbs. AT: "only those of you who give up all that you have can be my disciples" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])

tn.ref: give up all that he has
tn.text: "leave behind all that he has"
Jesus finishes teaching the crowd.
"Salt is useful." Jesus is teaching a lesson about those who want to be his disciple. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: how can it be made salty again?
tn.text: Jesus uses a question to teach the crowd. AT: "it cannot be made salty again" or "no one can make it salty again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
People use manure to fertilize gardens and fields. Salt without taste is so useless it is not even worth mixing with manure. AT: "compost heap" or "fertilizer"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "Someone just throws it away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: He who has ears to hear, let him hear
tn.text: It may be more natural in some languages to use the second person: "You who have ears to hear, hear" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: He who has ears to hear
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "Everyone" since everyone has ears or 2) "Whoever has the ability to understand" which refers to those who are willing to listen to God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"he should listen well" or "he should pay attention to what I say"
